segments.content: Last week I made a mistake, I sent out the 220 edition instead of 120 ğŸ˜… No one noticed, probably not a big deal!

segments.content: It's the conference season: the ViteConf replay is available, React Advanced just finished, and more to come.

segments.content: The Next.js conference starts in a few hours. We'll probably get a Next.js 13 announcement, along with nested layouts, and some other super cool stuff that starts with Turbo ğŸ¤­. Let's discuss that next week.

segments.content: We also have all the hosts agreeing to improve their Next.js support at the same time: Netlify, Cloudflare, Microsoft...

segments.content: [![Sizzy - the browser for developers](/emails/issues/220/sizzy.jpg)](https://sizzy.co/?utm_campaign=newsletter\&utm_source=thisweekinreact)
segments.sourceMdx: [![Sizzy - the browser for developers](/emails/issues/220/sizzy.jpg)](https://sizzy.co/?utm_campaign=newsletter&utm_source=thisweekinreact)

segments.content: How come professionals in every other industry have specialized tools, but web developers are still stuck using the browser that their grandma is using for shopping on Amazon?
segments.sourceMdx: How come professionals in every other industry have specialized tools, but web developers are still stuck using the browser that their grandma is using for shopping on Amazon?

segments.content: If you're opening localhost:3000 in any other browser except Sizzy, you're wasting hours of your precious time.
segments.sourceMdx: If you're opening localhost:3000 in any other browser except Sizzy, you're wasting hours of your precious time.

segments.content: **Before Sizzy:** web development is stressing you out, responsive design is hard, you have an overwhelming amount of opened tabs and apps.
segments.sourceMdx: **Before Sizzy:** web development is stressing you out, responsive design is hard, you have an overwhelming amount of opened tabs and apps.

segments.content: **After Sizzy:** all the tools you need are in one place, responsive design is a breeze, no more context switching.
segments.sourceMdx: **After Sizzy:** all the tools you need are in one place, responsive design is a breeze, no more context switching.

segments.content: You can [download it here](https://sizzy.co/?utm_campaign=newsletter\&utm_source=thisweekinreact) and try it for free for 14 days!

segments.content: ## âš›ï¸ React
segments.sourceMdx: ## âš›ï¸ React {#react}

segments.content: **[Why We're Breaking Up with CSS-in-JS](https://dev.to/srmagura/why-were-breaking-up-wiht-css-in-js-4g9b)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Why We're Breaking Up with CSS-in-JS](https://dev.to/srmagura/why-were-breaking-up-wiht-css-in-js-4g9b)**

segments.content: Sam is a maintainer of Emotion, one of the most popular CSS-in-JS libs. He explains the advantages and disadvantages of CSS-in-JS, with a focus on runtime libraries problems. For his company Spot, the cost of serializing styles was too high. They replaced Emotion by Sass modules (CSS modules + Sass) with a CSS utility system. On Docusaurus, we use CSS modules and I confirm that it is a good no-runtime and relatively simple alternative. DX is not as good but still quite acceptable.
segments.sourceMdx: Sam is a maintainer of Emotion, one of the most popular CSS-in-JS libs. He explains the advantages and disadvantages of CSS-in-JS, with a focus on runtime libraries problems. For his company Spot, the cost of serializing styles was too high. They replaced Emotion by Sass modules (CSS modules + Sass) with a CSS utility system. On Docusaurus, we use CSS modules and I confirm that it is a good no-runtime and relatively simple alternative. DX is not as good but still quite acceptable.

segments.content: This article has started many interesting discussions. It has been known for a while that CSS-in-JS libraries with runtime cause performance problems. [Dan Abramov confirms](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1584835028986793984) and [does not want to use any runtime on the new React doc site](https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/issues/5115). Ryan Florence mentions [performance problems with Chakra](https://twitter.com/ryanflorence/status/1582835729360572416), which uses Emotion.
segments.sourceMdx: This article has started many interesting discussions. It has been known for a while that CSS-in-JS libraries with runtime cause performance problems. [Dan Abramov confirms](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1584835028986793984) and [does not want to use any runtime on the new React doc site](https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/issues/5115). Ryan Florence mentions [performance problems with Chakra](https://twitter.com/ryanflorence/status/1582835729360572416), which uses Emotion.

segments.content: Tailwind remains a good alternative. For me, it can be put in the CSS-in-JS no-runtime category, especially in a React context where Tailwind styling is done via JSX. Some question its [maintainability](https://twitter.com/hi__mayank/status/1584261503670448128), but in practice it works quite well.
segments.sourceMdx: Tailwind remains a good alternative. For me, it can be put in the CSS-in-JS no-runtime category, especially in a React context where Tailwind styling is done via JSX. Some question its [maintainability](https://twitter.com/hi__mayank/status/1584261503670448128), but in practice it works quite well.

segments.content: **[Qwik React](https://qwik.builder.io/qwikcity/integrations/react/)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Qwik React](https://qwik.builder.io/qwikcity/integrations/react/)**

segments.content: Qwik is an innovative SPA framework that [avoids performance issues related to client-side hydration](https://www.builder.io/blog/hydration-is-pure-overhead). It can now integrate with React through a `qwikify$()` function to wrap any existing React component. `client:` directives (inspired by Astro) allow to control when the React component will be hydrated with a lot of granularity. The demo integrates Material UI in a Qwik app. See also [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLH28rDu97I). I think it's a good solution to avoid doing an all-in on this new framework, and try it gradually. We can also keep the cross-platform properties of React, while adopting Qwik to improve performance on the web.
segments.sourceMdx: Qwik is an innovative SPA framework that [avoids performance issues related to client-side hydration](https://www.builder.io/blog/hydration-is-pure-overhead). It can now integrate with React through a `qwikify$()` function to wrap any existing React component. `client:` directives (inspired by Astro) allow to control when the React component will be hydrated with a lot of granularity. The demo integrates Material UI in a Qwik app. See also [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLH28rDu97I). I think it's a good solution to avoid doing an all-in on this new framework, and try it gradually. We can also keep the cross-platform properties of React, while adopting Qwik to improve performance on the web.

segments.content: **[Fully Typed Web Apps](https://www.epicweb.dev/fully-typed-web-apps)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Fully Typed Web Apps](https://www.epicweb.dev/fully-typed-web-apps)**

segments.content: Kent C. Dodds explains the interest of having end to end type-safety, from the DB to the UI, through the different boundaries: network, localstorage, DB... He talks about validation (schema, type guards), type generation (Prisma) and conventions (Remix). He explains how this experience is possible with Remix, thanks to inference: it is better to use `typeof` than `as`.
segments.sourceMdx: Kent C. Dodds explains the interest of having end to end type-safety, from the DB to the UI, through the different boundaries: network, localstorage, DB... He talks about validation (schema, type guards), type generation (Prisma) and conventions (Remix). He explains how this experience is possible with Remix, thanks to inference: it is better to use `typeof` than `as`.

segments.content: **[Building an interactive WebGL experience in Next.js](https://vercel.com/blog/building-an-interactive-webgl-experience-in-next-js)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Building an interactive WebGL experience in Next.js](https://vercel.com/blog/building-an-interactive-webgl-experience-in-next-js)**

segments.content: Vercel explains how they created an [impressive immersive signup experience for the Next.js conf](https://nextjs.org/conf), based on React-Three-Fiber. It's still complex to understand without 3D / WebGL / Three.js experience, but the deconstruction in successive steps is interesting and gives an insight into the mindset of doing creative dev.
segments.sourceMdx: Vercel explains how they created an [impressive immersive signup experience for the Next.js conf](https://nextjs.org/conf), based on React-Three-Fiber. It's still complex to understand without 3D / WebGL / Three.js experience, but the deconstruction in successive steps is interesting and gives an insight into the mindset of doing creative dev.

segments.content:
* ğŸ‘€ [React Cache API Pull-Request](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/25506): exposes a new `React.experimental_cache` API
* ğŸ“– [New beta doc - cloneElement](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1582814754426433537)
* ğŸ“¦ [Vitest Preview](https://www.vitest-preview.com/): permits to visually debug Vitest tests. Little brother of [Jest Preview](https://www.jest-preview.com/).
* ğŸ“¦ [Outstatic - A static CMS for Next.js](https://outstatic.com/): new Git-based CMS that integrates nicely with Next.js. Simple user-friendly editor with the ability to upload images.
* ğŸ“œ [Netlify - Background and Scheduled API Routes for Next.js](https://www.netlify.com/blog/new-background-scheduled-api-routes-nextjs/): Netlify using its background functions to call Next.js API based on cron expressions.
* ğŸ“œ [Cloudflare Pages support for Next.js Edge Runtime](https://blog.cloudflare.com/next-on-pages/): Cloudflare now supports Next.js, only via the `experimental-edge` runtime that can run on Cloudflare Workers (unlike the Node.js runtime). Their solution is based on [Vercel Build Output API](https://vercel.com/blog/build-output-api), which seems to pave the way for better portability of edge-first frameworks between different clouds.
* ğŸ“œ [Microsoft - Extending Next.js support in Azure Static Web Apps](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/apps-on-azure-blog/extending-next-js-support-in-azure-static-web-apps/ba-p/3627975): Azure will now support Next.js SSR (previously: only SSG).
* ğŸ“œ [Persist inputs after a form submit in Remix](https://sergiodxa.com/articles/persist-inputs-after-a-form-submit-in-remix): proposes a progressive enhancement solution to keep the values of a form after a submission. 2 solutions: return the values in the Remix action or use the flash session.
* ğŸ“œ [Currying Layout Component Patterns in Next.js](https://creativedesignsguru.com/currying-nextjs-layout/): suggest to parametrize the `getLayout` of Next.js to create Layout variants without leading to unmount/remount. Nice trick today, might become less relevant with the upcoming nested layouts support.
* ğŸ“œ [Throwing vs. Returning responses in Remix](https://sergiodxa.com/articles/throwing-vs-returning-responses-in-remix)
* ğŸ“œ [Lessons learned from moving to Recoil.js](https://kitemaker.co/blog/lessons-learned-from-moving-to-recoil)
* ğŸ“œ [Separate API Layers In React Apps](https://profy.dev/article/react-architecture-api-layer)
* ğŸ¥ [Is the new React use hook a footgun?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ytXM05PVcFU)
* ğŸ¥ [React Advanced London 2022 - Day 1](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1x7mI_xuVVo)
* ğŸ§µ [Lottie vs Rive](https://twitter.com/guidorosso/status/1582086637328031745): Lottie is quite popular in the React ecosystem but its competitor Rive looks much more performant at runtime.
* ğŸ¦ [Zustand code in a tweet](https://twitter.com/dai_shi/status/1583082766081531905)
* ğŸ”— [New website for Storybook](https://twitter.com/storybookjs/status/1583175829009289216)

segments.content: **[How 1000s of software engineers stay productive without burning out](https://www.sunsama.com/a/this-week-in-react)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[How 1000s of software engineers stay productive without burning out](https://www.sunsama.com/a/this-week-in-react)**

segments.content: You know that the output of your work matters more than the number of hours you put in. **[Sunsama](https://www.sunsama.com/a/this-week-in-react)** has been the insider secret of 1000s of developers who use it to work less but achieve more.
segments.sourceMdx: You know that the output of your work matters more than the number of hours you put in. **[Sunsama](https://www.sunsama.com/a/this-week-in-react)** has been the insider secret of 1000s of developers who use it to work less but achieve more.

segments.content: Eliminate endless tab-switching with their JIRA, Github, and Notion integration. Timebox your day and create space for your hobbies and side-projects.
segments.sourceMdx: Eliminate endless tab-switching with their JIRA, Github, and Notion integration. Timebox your day and create space for your hobbies and side-projects.

segments.content: The best part? They're offering a **[14-day free trial](https://www.sunsama.com/a/this-week-in-react)** (no card needed) so you can start achieving more, today.

segments.content: ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼ [**Product Engineer at Causal, Remote/London/NY, $150-250k**](https://jobs.lever.co/causal-app/4acaafbe-ef3d-45a6-bbe6-687c022d727c?lever-origin=applied\&lever-source%5B%5D=thisweekinreact.com)
segments.sourceMdx: ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼ [**Product Engineer at Causal, Remote/London/NY, $150-250k**](https://jobs.lever.co/causal-app/4acaafbe-ef3d-45a6-bbe6-687c022d727c?lever-origin=applied&lever-source%5B%5D=thisweekinreact.com)

segments.content: Causal is a Series A Startup (backed by Coatue/Accel) building an all-in-one tool for working with numbers and visualizing data. We're looking for strong React engineers who can solve difficult UX/performance challenges.
segments.sourceMdx: Causal is a Series A Startup (backed by Coatue/Accel) building an all-in-one tool for working with numbers and visualizing data. We're looking for strong React engineers who can solve difficult UX/performance challenges.

segments.content: ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼ [**G2i - 100% Remote React Native Jobs**](https://twitter.com/gabe_g2i/status/1563204813881425926?s=20\&t=ArRLC77BpRwXXCdx8fnUqw)
segments.sourceMdx: ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼ [**G2i - 100% Remote React Native Jobs**](https://twitter.com/gabe_g2i/status/1563204813881425926?s=20&t=ArRLC77BpRwXXCdx8fnUqw)

segments.content: We have several roles open for developers focused on React Native! Pay is \~160k plus 10% bonus. You must have production experience with RN and be based in the US. DM [@gabe\_g2i](https://twitter.com/gabe_g2i) to learn more and don't forget to mention This Week in React.

segments.content: ## ğŸ”€ Other
segments.sourceMdx: ## ğŸ”€ Other {#other}

segments.content:
* [Letâ€™s talk about web components](https://bradfrost.com/blog/post/lets-talk-about-web-components/): Interesting reading by Brad Frost on Web Components, which are not necessarily incompatible with React but can complement it (e.g.: a design system in a React app). The current difficulties (SSR) will eventually be overcome.
* [Replit App](https://twitter.com/amasad/status/1582754714575257600): new app to code on your phone (made with [Expo](https://twitter.com/amasad/status/1582968657675661314)). There are templates to code in Next.js.
* [Introducing Node.js 19](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/introducing-nodejs-19) - Note: Node.js 18 enters LTS today!
* [Introducing Stately Studio 1.0](https://stately.ai/blog/introducing-stately-studio-10): XState state machine editor
* [Vite 4 plans](https://github.com/vitejs/vite/discussions/10570): upgrade to Rollup 3, es2020 compat...
* [ViteConf 2022 replay](https://viteconf.org/2022/replay)
* [Turborepo 1.6 - Use Turborepo in non-monorepos](https://twitter.com/turborepo/status/1583518617970233346)
* [Solid 1.6](https://twitter.com/solid_js/status/1583016386984480768)
* [Futuristic CSS](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/10/futuristic-css/)
* [Is There Too Much CSS Now?](https://css-tricks.com/is-there-too-much-css-now/)
* [npm bin script confusion: Abusing â€˜binâ€™ to hijack â€˜nodeâ€™ command](https://socket.dev/blog/npm-bin-script-confusion)
* [Tailwind CSS v3.2: Dynamic breakpoints, multi-config, and container queries](https://twitter.com/adamwathan/status/1582793658168152065)
* [Tailwind CSS v3.2: revisiting my â€œfeature creepâ€ warning](https://www.brycewray.com/posts/2022/10/tailwind-css-v3-2-revisiting-feature-creep-warning/)
* [Can I DevTools - Compare the features of browsers DevTools. ](https://canidev.tools)
* [Vercel - Regional Edge Functions](https://vercel.com/blog/regional-execution-for-ultra-low-latency-rendering-at-the-edge)
* [Deno - Which serverless edge platform has the fastest git deployments?](https://deno.com/blog/fastest-git-deploys-to-the-edge)
* [Cloudflare Workers and micro-frontends: made for one another](https://blog.cloudflare.com/better-micro-frontends/)
* [Blink: Intent to Ship: CSS Color Module Level 4 + color-mix()](https://twitter.com/intenttoship/status/1583110354074116096)
* [Release Notes for Safari Technology Preview 156](https://webkit.org/blog/13394/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-156/)
* [WebKit Features in Safari 16.1](https://webkit.org/blog/13399/webkit-features-in-safari-16-1/)
* [JavaScript metaprogramming with the 2022-03 decorators API](https://2ality.com/2022/10/javascript-decorators.html)
